SENT.plain: Lym-I is a murine IgG2a monoclonal antibody (MAb) that is B-cell specific but has greater avidity for malignant B cells when compared with normal B lymphocytes
It was originally produced by immunizing mice with nuclei of cultured cells from a patient with Burkitt's lymphoma
Ten patients with progressive refractory B-cell malignancies were treated with 131I-labelled Lym-I
Treatment with 131I Lym-I produced complete or partial remissions in 4 patients
Toxicity did not occur or was mild in most patients
The only significant complications included two instances of fistula secondary to necrotic lymphoma and one instance of hypotension
Human antimouse antibodies occurred in only 2 patients after multiple injections of Lym-I antibody
This experience was in contrast to treatment of B-cell malignancies with unconjugated Lym-I alone
Unconjugated Lym-I also caused no significant toxicity but was less effective than 131I Lym-I
